Authors:
Ni-Ni Win, Takeaki Hanyuda, Stefano G. A. Draisma, Giovanni
Furnari, Alexandre Meinesz, Hiroshi Kawai
Title:
Padina ditristromatica sp. nov. and Padina pavonicoides sp.
nov. (Dictyotales, Phaeophyceae), two new species from the Mediterranean
Sea based on morphological and molecular markers
Keywords:
cox3, Dictyotales, Mediterranean Sea, molecular analyses,
Padina ditristromatica, Padina pavonicoides, Phaeophyceae, rbcL,
taxonomy
Abstract:
A study of the genus Padina in the Mediterranean Sea based
on detailed morphological and molecular analyses using chloroplast rbcL
and mitochondrial cox3 gene sequences, as well as RuBisCO spacer and
partial rbcS sequences revealed the presence of two new species, P.
ditristromatica Ni-Ni-Win et H. Kawai and P. pavonicoides Ni-Ni-Win et
H. Kawai. They are 2 to 3-layered and 3-layered species, respectively.
Padina ditristromatica is characterized by a thallus composed of two
cell layers from the marginal portion to the inrolled margin and a
mixture of two and three layers in the other portions, heavy
calcification on both surfaces of the thallus except for the hair lines,
the alternating hair lines arranged in unequal distance between both
surfaces, and broad indusiate oogonial and tetrasporangial sori forming
broken lines or patches arranged in a concentric row, which are distally
close to the hair lines and half immersed in the epidermis layer only on
the inferior surface. Padina pavonicoides is characterized by a thallus
composed of three cell layers from the base to the marginal portion and
two layers at the inrolled margin, the alternating hair lines arranged
in equal distance between both surfaces, and indusiate oogonial and
tetrasporangial sori forming patches located distal to the hair lines
only on the inferior surface. All molecular phylogenetic analyses
indicated that they are closely related to P. pavonica (Linnaeus) Thivy,
a common species in the Mediterranean Sea. However, the cox3 region
could not be amplified for P. ditristromatica. Therefore, the RuBisCO
spacer and partial rbcS were analysed for the Mediterranean specimens in
order to confirm their identity as well as their closest relationship.
The combined rbcL, RuBisCO spacer and partial rbcS data also supports
their genetic separation and shows that P. pavonica is more closely
related to P. pavonicoides than P. ditristromatica as in other molecular
analyses.
